title: 113_s179
content: The "Gun Trafficking Prevention Act of 2013" may be cited as the Act. It addresses firearms trafficking. The "Gun Trafficking Prevention Act of 2013" addresses trafficking in firearms, making it unlawful to ship, transport, or receive two or more firearms in interstate or foreign commerce if there is knowledge or reasonable cause to believe it would violate federal, state, or local laws. The "Gun Trafficking Prevention Act of 2013" prohibits the receipt of firearms if it violates any law punishable by imprisonment exceeding 1 year, making false statements about a buyer, or directing illegal conduct. There are exceptions for lawfully acquired firearms given to non-prohibited individuals. The "Gun Trafficking Prevention Act of 2013" prohibits the receipt of firearms if it violates any law punishable by imprisonment exceeding 1 year. Exceptions include gifts to non-prohibited individuals or acquisitions by court-appointed trustees. Violators face fines, imprisonment up to 20 years, or both. Organizer enhancement applies if the violation involves 5 or more individuals under the organizer's supervision. The "Gun Trafficking Prevention Act of 2013" imposes additional imprisonment of up to 5 years for individuals in supervisory positions involved in firearms trafficking. Definitions for "actual buyer" and "term of imprisonment exceeding 1 year" are provided in the subsection. The "Gun Trafficking Prevention Act of 2013" adds penalties for firearms trafficking, with the Sentencing Commission tasked to review and amend sentencing guidelines for such offenses. The Sentencing Commission is directed to increase penalties for violations of firearms trafficking when committed by individuals involved in criminal organizations.
